column1: Shakshi	Imran Khan	Individual	aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/28/pakistan-to-hold-talks-with-india-if-siege-on-kashmir-is-lifted	"Imran Khan says he is open to dialogue if Kashmiris are given the right to self-determination as per the UN resolutions.
Islamabad
column2: Pakistan – Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has reiterated that he is prepared to hold talks with neighbouring India only if it lifts its “military siege” on Indian-administered Kashmir and gives its residents the right to self-determination.

column1: Khan made the remarks during a short video address released on Tuesday to coincide with the anniversary of the day Indian security forces entered the part of Kashmir it administers in 1947
column2: two months after both India and Pakistan gained independence from the British.

column1: In his speech
column2: Khan said he would engage in dialogue with India only if it took steps to reverse what Pakistan terms New Delhi’s “occupation” of India’s only Muslim-majority region.

column1: “I am ready [for talks]
column2: but for that
column3: you will need to end the military siege that you have imposed on Kashmir
column4: and the second thing is that you will need to give Kashmiris the right to self-determination as per the United Nations’ resolutions
column5: ” said Khan.

column1: Both India and Pakistan claim Kashmir in full but administer separate portions of it
column2: divided by a Line of Control
column3: across which a tenuous ceasefire has been in place since 2003.

column1: In August 2019
column2: India revoked a constitutional provision that had given Indian-administered Kashmir a measure of autonomy
column3: bringing it into the country’s administrative and governance mainstream.

column1: The move was accompanied by the influx of tens of thousands of troops into the territory
column2: where an armed separatist movement has raged for years.

column1: A curfew was imposed across the mountainous Himalayan territory
column2: with severe restrictions on public gatherings
column3: communication and other civil liberties and hundreds of people arrested.

column1: The restrictions have continued after the coronavirus pandemic erupted in March.
In his comments on Tuesday
column2: Khan decried what he termed a “military siege” of Kashmir’s citizens in Indian-administered Kashmir.

column1: “They are neither Indian citizens
column2: and neither do they have the right of self-determination that was given by the United Nations Security Council
column3: ” he said.

column2: the UN Security Council passed a resolution mandating that both sides cease hostilities to pave the way for a plebiscite where Kashmiris would be given the right to choose between joining either Pakistan or India.

column1: But New Delhi has continued to tighten its control over the Muslim-majority region with a large military presence and a series of legislation aimed at suppressing the separatist voices.
Khan’s statement on Tuesday coincided with India enacting new laws that allow any Indian national to buy land in Indian-administered Kashmir
column2: spurring allegations about New Delhi planning a demographic change in the region.

column1: Returning stolen artifacts to their countries of origin is a good thing. It reverses the drain on cultural heritage that occurs during conflicts and builds up good will between countries. But how much is this impacting the illegal antiquities trade in general? Several recent studies suggest the trade continues on a massive scale
column2: despite the work of governments
column3: law enforcement
column4: and institutions such as the British Museum. The studies also show that antiquities traffickers favor coins and other small finds — items of little value individually but that add up in bulk
column5: and that can be smuggled easily — not the unique sculptural pieces typically announced by the British Museum. While they may grab headlines
column6: the museum’s efforts are a drop in the bucket.

column1: Ironically
column2: Dr St John Simpson
column3: the British Museum curator most directly involved with the identification and return of these trafficked artifacts
column4: has consistently downplayed the level of antiquities looting and smuggling going on today. Simpson insists that most antiquities looting in Iraq ended in the immediate aftermath of the 2003 US invasion
column5: despite Iraqi claims to the contrary. He has also suggested that no artifacts can be proven to have entered the UK from Syria in the last nine years while dismissing the overwhelming evidence of large-scale looting during that country’s civil war.

column1: It is also ironic to see the British Museum at the forefront of cultural heritage repatriation. The museum is infamous for failing to seriously address how it acquired much of its own collection — most notably the Parthenon sculptures (known as the “Elgin marbles”)
column2: but also the Benin bronzes
column3: the Maqdala collection
column4: and many other artifacts. “The world’s largest receiver of stolen goods” is what a leading human rights lawyer
column5: Geoffrey Robertson
column6: called the museum in the Guardian last November. A day after the Guardian article
column7: Robertson’s book Who Owns History? Elgin’s Loot and the Case for Returning Plundered Treasure came out – and so did a British Museum blog post by St John Simpson on the British Museum’s work “identifying and returning looted objects.” The timing is suggestive. Does the museum use its work policing the antiquities market to distract from its historic role in acquiring looted and smuggled objects?

column1: Museum public relations presents its work in identifying trafficked antiquities as an altruistic enterprise. “The British Museum is absolutely committed to the fight against illicit trade and damage to cultural heritage
column2: ” director Hartwig Fischer assures the public in the museum’s press release for the Sumerian plaque. Earlier this year
column3: Fischer praised the museum’s efforts “in the reconstruction of the rich cultural heritage of Afghanistan after decades of conflict
column4: destruction and loss.” What goes unmentioned is that the British Museum receives many benefits from this and other cultural heritage efforts. For instance

column102: and that can be smuggled easily — not the unique sculptural pieces typically announced by the British Museum. While they may grab headlines

the museum’s efforts are a drop in the bucket.

column105: the British Museum curator most directly involved with the identification and return of these trafficked artifacts
column106: has consistently downplayed the level of antiquities looting and smuggling going on today. Simpson insists that most antiquities looting in Iraq ended in the immediate aftermath of the 2003 US invasion
column107:
despite Iraqi claims to the contrary. He has also suggested that no artifacts can be proven to have entered the UK from Syria in the last nine years while dismissing the overwhelming evidence of large-scale looting during that country’s civil war.

It is also ironic to see the British Museum at the forefront of cultural heritage repatriation. The museum is infamous for failing to seriously address how it acquired much of its own collection —\xa0 most notably the Parthenon sculptures (known as the “Elgin marbles”)
column110: and many other artifacts. “The world’s largest receiver of stolen goods” is what a leading human rights lawyer
column112: called the museum in the Guardian last November. A day after the Guardian article
column113:

Does the museum use its work policing the antiquities market to distract from its historic role in acquiring looted and smuggled objects?

column114: ” director Hartwig Fischer assures the public in the museum’s press release for the Sumerian plaque. Earlier this year
column115: Fischer praised the museum’s efforts “in the reconstruction of the rich cultural heritage of Afghanistan after decades of conflict

column117: it gets to put many of the trafficked artifacts it identifies on temporary display before handing them over to their source countries. (The Sumerian plaque is currently on temporary display at the British Museum.) And throughout

it gets glowing press coverage.

The British Museum could use its work identifying smuggled antiquities to take a thoughtful look at its own past. Instead
column119: we get empty clichés. The reality is that cultural heritage is determined by the powerful for their own benefit

column1: Carel	William Gale	Individual	https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jul/06/gen-z-covid-19-financial-crisis-lasting-scars	"Graduation was supposed to be one of the best moments of Stephany Torres’s life.
As a first-generation student at the University of California Los Angeles
column2: Torres was looking forward to celebrating her new degree with friends and family. After graduation
column3: she was supposed to have an internship at a law firm in Los Angeles
column4: making new connections and getting more insight into the type of law she wants to study.

column1: Instead
column2: graduation and the internship were cancelled. Torres
column4: who is from South Central Los Angeles
column5: was laid off from her on-campus job that was helping her pay her rent and support her mother. She moved back home
column6: and while she is planning on taking on a research position at UCLA
column7: she has been trying to look for paid positions in the legal field.

column1: “I had built up my resume to land an internship like this
column2: ” Torres said. “When that was taken from me it was really hard because I just feel so much uncertainty right now.”

column1: The coronavirus pandemic has hit every generation hard
column2: disproportionately killing older Americans and spreading economic fear across the entire country. For Gen Z
column3: people born between 1997 and 2012
column4: life has practically been upended and the ramifications of the virus and the financial crisis it has engendered threatens their livelihoods for years to come.

column1: The unemployment rate for teens ages 16 to 19 peaked at 31% in April
column2: more than double the national rate of 14.7%. College graduates who only months ago were on track to enter one of the best job markets in US history have instead landed in one of the worst. A slate of summer internships and jobs have been cancelled and they are worried about their parents struggling to pay bills.

column1: A good chunk of Gen Z is still in school – the youngest are just eight years old. But for older “zoomers”
column2: the effects of this economic downturn will likely be felt for years as they try to start careers and build savings with an economy that was struck to rubble.

column1: “Early career events like this tend to have scarring effects
column2: they tend to persist over time
column3: ” said William Gale
column4: a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. “The jobs available or the wages available won’t be as good as they would have been otherwise.”

column1: Grace Miller
column3: who will be a junior at Penn State University in the fall
column4: emailed a local newspaper about potential internships before shutdowns began. She was told that she could potentially take on a paid position instead of an internship
column5: but the publication stopped responding to her inquiries once shutdowns began.

column1: Instead Miller is working at a restaurant this summer
column2: trying to build up savings for rent and textbooks for the next school year. Her dream is to eventually work in a city like New York or Los Angeles
column3: but she is unsure whether that dream will be a reality in a post-pandemic world.

column1: “With journalism
column2: there are so many newsrooms that are already struggling for money that are already cutting jobs. [Getting a job] was already going to be difficult in the first place
column3: but add in this whole new situation and it’s concerning
column4: ” Miller said. “I’d like to think that by the time I graduate
column5: maybe this will all be over
column6: but I really highly doubt that.”

column1: The US has already seen how a recession can undermine a whole generation’s ability to navigate their careers and build wealth: millennials
column2: the group of people born between 1980 and 1996
column3: have pretty much been defined by the effects of the last recession.

column1: Research shows that the oldest millennials never fully recovered after the last recession hit the job and housing market. Millennials lost an estimated 13% of earnings from job cuts and reduced wages during the recession that they never got back.
A reduction in earning creates a cascading effect
column2: especially since millennials are likely to have thousands of dollars of student and medical debt. And while those without a college degree may not have student debt
column3: they are making far less than those with a college degree – a gap that has widened over the last few decades.

column1: Debt makes it harder for a person to save and accumulate wealth in the form of assets. Young Americans have delayed buying homes
column2: the most common way the average American builds wealth
column3: due to debt and rising housing costs. Millennials have also delayed major life events
column4: like starting families.

column1: “Wealth inequality has worsened over the past 50 years
column2: and you start to look at what groups are affected
column3: and its young Americans
column4: ” said Signe-Mary McKernan
column5: a vice president at the Urban Institute. “They’re barely breaking even with their parents. It used to be in America that every generation did better than the previous generation
column6: but that’s no longer necessarily the case.”

column1: The burden of debt and lack of wealth in the millennial cohort has had major health consequences. A report from the Stanford Center on Poverty and Inequality found that from 2008 and 2016
column2: the mortality rates of people between the ages of 25 and 34 increased 20%
column3: largely because of suicides and drug overdoses. These kinds of deaths
column4: often called “ deaths of despair ” are closely tied to the economic troubles a person experiences that leads to hopelessness.

column1: Gen Z is
column2: of course
column3: different from millennials
column4: as members of the former love to point out. But David Grusky
column5: a professor who put together the Stanford report
column6: said millennials are the “canaries in the coal mine who reveal just how toxic these problems are”.

column1: There is some hope that Gen Z is learning something from its elders. A study from earlier this year showed that Gen Z was increasingly careful with money and less likely to take out student loans than millennials.
Cyril King
column3: of West Haven
column4: Connecticut
column5: unenrolled from his dream school because the university was asking him to pay too much tuition – $35
column6: 000 – out of pocket. Losing a job he had in the spring hurt his finances
column7: so King decided to enroll at Colgate University
column8: which provided more financial aid and guaranteed that he would graduate debt free.

column1: “I have dreams and aspirations. I want to help people. I want to be a lawyer
column2: hopefully representing people who are unrepresented. Going to law school is another thing as well
column3: so getting to leave without being in debt is perfect to me
column4: ” King said.

column1: Many in Gen Z are also watching their parents struggle with unemployment or reduced hours at work amid shutdown orders and are aware their families cannot handle a big expense like college.
Taylor Pittman
column3: of New Orleans
column4: Louisiana
column5: said getting a full-ride scholarship to a college is the goal motivating her into her senior year of high school. Pittman has four internships this summer
column6: all while helping care for her younger brother as her parents continue to work.

column1: “I really just want [college] to be free so my mom and dad don’t have to stress out about paying for anything related to school
column2: ” Pittman said. “My mom and dad’s pockets can only stretch so far.”

column1: When it came to deciding what college to go to
column2: Jonathan Donis
column4: of Los Angeles made a list of schools that provided him with enough financial aid to graduate debt-free. The pandemic hit his family hard. His parents
column5: essential workers who cannot work from home
column6: have been working reduced hours and are seeing lower wages.

column1: By going to college
column2: Donis
column3: who is going to Stanford University in the fall
column4: hopes he can use his education to eventually help support his parents and his younger siblings.

column1: “My parents always joke around like ‘you’re going to buy me a house when you graduate
column2: right?’. I’m like
column3: yeah

\n

Graduation was supposed to be one of the best moments of Stephany Torres’s life.

\n

As a first-generation student at the University of California Los Angeles
column103: Torres was looking forward to celebrating her new degree with friends and family. After graduation
column104: she was supposed to have an internship at a law firm in Los Angeles
column105:
making new connections and getting more insight into the type of law she wants to study.

\n

Instead
column106: graduation and the internship were cancelled. Torres
column108: who is from South Central Los Angeles
column109: was laid off from her on-campus job that was helping her pay her rent and support her mother. She moved back home
column110: and while she is planning on taking on a research position at UCLA
column111:
she has been trying to look for paid positions in the legal field.

\n

“I had built up my resume to land an internship like this
column112: ” Torres said. “When that was taken from me it was really hard because I just feel so much uncertainty right now.”

column115: disproportionately killing older Americans and spreading economic fear across the entire country. For Gen Z
column117:
life has practically been upended and the ramifications of the virus and the financial crisis it has engendered threatens their livelihoods for years to come.

The unemployment rate for teens ages 16 to 19 peaked at 31% in April
column118:
more than double the national rate of 14.7%. College graduates who only months ago were on track to enter one of the best job markets in US history have instead landed in one of the worst. A slate of summer internships and jobs have been cancelled and they are worried about their parents struggling to pay bills.

\n

A good chunk of Gen Z is still in school – the youngest are just eight years old. But for older “zoomers”
column119:
the effects of this economic downturn will likely be felt for years as they try to start careers and build savings with an economy that was struck to rubble.

\n

“Early career events like this tend to have scarring effects
column120: they tend to persist over time
column122:
a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. “The jobs available or the wages available won’t be as good as they would have been otherwise.”

\n

Grace Miller
column124: who will be a junior at Penn State University in the fall
column125: emailed a local newspaper about potential internships before shutdowns began. She was told that she could potentially take on a paid position instead of an internship
column126:
but the publication stopped responding to her inquiries once shutdowns began.

\n

Instead Miller is working at a restaurant this summer
column127: trying to build up savings for rent and textbooks for the next school year. Her dream is to eventually work in a city like New York or Los Angeles
column128:
but she is unsure whether that dream will be a reality in a post-pandemic world.

\n

“With journalism
column129: there are so many newsrooms that are already struggling for money that are already cutting jobs. [Getting a job] was already going to be difficult in the first place
column130: but add in this whole new situation and it’s concerning
column131: ” Miller said. “I’d like to think that by the time I graduate
column132: maybe this will all be over
column133: but I really highly doubt that.”

A reduction in earning creates a cascading effect
column138: especially since millennials are likely to have thousands of dollars of student and medical debt. And while those without a college degree may not have student debt
column139:
they are making far less than those with a college degree – a gap that has widened over the last few decades.

column147:

column148: the mortality rates of people between the ages of 25 and 34 increased 20%

often called “deaths of despair” are closely tied to the economic troubles a person experiences that leads to hopelessness.

said millennials are the “canaries in the coal mine who reveal just how toxic these problems are”.

Hong Kong (CNN Business)HSBC (HSBC) said on Monday that escalating tensions between China and the West are creating ""challenging situations"" for its business after the global bank reported a 65% plunge in profits in the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

The London-based lender

""We will face any political challenges that arise with a focus on the long-term needs of our customers and the best interests of our investors

he added.

mainly in Europe.""

hurting profits even more.

Now

the Chinese tech giant. The bank last weekdenied those allegations.

\n\n

But almost as soon as Mugabe was imprisoned
column152: a man in her majesty’s employ travelled down from his advisory post in newly free Zambia to visit the prisoner. Dennis Grennan returned to Lusaka having\xa0promised\xa0to look after Mugabe’s wife Sarah
column153:
known as “Sally”. Grennan and people like Julius Nyerere’s British friend and assistant\xa0Joan Wicken\xa0played an important role in Mugabe’s rise.

\n\n

The Zimbabwean nationalists emerged from Salisbury’s prisons late in 1974
column154: as Portugal’s coup led to Angola and Mozambique emerging from colonialism into the Soviet orbit. The fifties generation of Zimbabwean nationalists were to participate in the Zambian and South African inspired détente\xa0exercise. This inspired much competition for Zanu’s leadership: Mugabe arrived in Lusaka after ousting Ndabaningi Sithole
column157:
wondered if Mugabe’s quick rise was due to a\xa0“coup in prison”. Herbert Chitepo’s March 1975\xa0assassination \xa0(which got many of Zanu’s leaders arrested and its army kicked out of Zambia) was only one marker of the many fissures in the fractious party that by 1980 would rule Zimbabwe.

\n\n

In late 1975 the\xa0vashandi\xa0group emerged within the Zimbabwean People’s Army. Based in Mozambique’s guerrilla camps
column158:
they tried to forge unity between Zimbabwe’s two main nationalist armies and push a left-wing agenda. They were profoundly unsure of Mugabe’s suitability for\xa0leadership.

\n\n

When Mugabe found his way to Mozambique also in late 1975
column159: Machel put him under house arrest in Quelimane
column160:
far from the guerrilla camps. In January Grennan helped him to London to visit a hospitalised Sally. He made contacts around Europe and with a few\xa0London-based Maoists.

\n\n

Soon after Mugabe’s return the young American congressman Stephen Solarz and the Deputy Head of the American embassy in Maputo
column162:
wended their way to\xa0Quelimane. Mugabe wowed them.

\n\n

Solarz and Carson reported back that Mugabe was “an impressive
column163:
articulate and extremely confident individual” with a “philosophical approach to problems and … well reasoned arguments”. He claimed to control the “people’s army”.

\n\n

Yet by January 1977
column164: he persuaded Samora Machel to imprison the young advocates of unity with Zapu. His many reasons included their initial refusal to support him at a late 1976 conference in Geneva organised by the British
column166:
the American Secretary of State.

\n\n

At a hastily called congress in March 1977 to consecrate his ascension
column167:
Mugabe uttered his leitmotif: those appearing to attempt a change to the party’s leadership by “maliciously planting contradictions within our ranks” would be struck by the\xa0“the Zanu axe”.

\n\n

This was Mugabe’s strategy
column168: embedded at an early stage: tell foreign emissaries what they wanted to hear
column169: use young radicals (or older allies) until their usefulness subsided
column170:
and then get rid of them.

\n\n

All the while he would balance the other forces contending for power in the party amid a general climate of fear
column172:
and paranoia.

Dealing with dissent

It is not certain if Margaret Thatcher knew about this side of Mugabe when they met less than a month after his April 1980 inauguration.

He seemed most worried about how Joshua Nkomo’s Zapu – which he had dumped from the erstwhile “Patriotic Front”
column173:
and the violence against which had put Zimbabwe’s election in some doubt – was making life difficult for the new rulers. He\xa0warned\xa0that he might have “to act against them soon”.

\n\n

In as much as Zapu was linked with the South African ANC and Thatcher and her colleagues tended to think the ANC was controlled by the South African Communist Party
column174:
Zapu intelligence chief\xa0Dumiso Dabengwa’s\xa0perspective might be more than conspiracy theory.

Perhaps Thatcher’s wink and nudge was a green light for the anti-Soviet contingent to eliminate a regional threat. Gukurahundi\xa0followed.

It was certainly the biggest blot on Mugabe’s career and created the biggest scar over Zimbabwe. The scar is still there
column175: given the lack of any effort at reconcialitation
column177:
or justice.

Four years later the ruling party’s first real congress since 1963 reviewed its history. Mugabe tore the Zipa/Vashandi group that had annoyed him eight years before to shreds. “Treacherous … counter-revolutionary … arms caching … dubbed us all\xa0zvigananda\xa0or bourgeois”. Thus it “became imperative for us to firmly act against them in defending the Party and the Revolution… We had all the trouble-makers detained”.

The great helmsman recounted the youthful dissenters’ arrest and repeated the axe phraseology.

But few saw these sides of Mugabe’s character soon enough; those who did were summarily shut up.

The end

After he’d been ousted
column178:
Mugabe could only look on in seeming despair over the ruination he had created.

\n\n

Sanctimonious as ever he wondered how his successor
column180:
had become such an ogre.

\n\n

At his 95th birthday
column182: a few weeks after Mnangagwa’s troops had killed 17 demonstrators
column184: and beaten hundreds more in the wake of his beleaguered finance minister’s methods to create\xa0“prosperity from austerity”
column185:
Mugabe\xa0mused to his absent successor:

""We condemn the violence on civilians by soldiers … You can’t do without seeing dead bodies? What kind of a person are you? You feed on death?""

He only had to look into his own history to see what kind of people he helped create.

David B. Moore is a Visiting Fellow
column187:
University of Cambridge and Professor of Development Studies at University of Johannesburg

column2: it needs to stop tussling with Western investors. The arbitration filings came just days after Tbilisi backed down in another conflict with another investor
column3: Frontera
column4: an American oil company – under myopic pressure from Washington.

column1: This latest escalation in the bitter public dispute over Anaklia is a blow to Georgia’s national security for two reasons.
First
column2: it is yet more evidence that Anaklia will not be built anytime soon; the arbitration process will make it difficult for the government to attract new investors. As the country’s first deep-water port
column3: Anaklia is an essential part of Georgia’s plan to transform itself into a transit hub between Europe and Asia
column4: a strategy intended to boost trade
column5: integrate deeper in the Euro-Atlantic economic system
column6: and ultimately pull Georgia out of Russia’s sphere of influence.

column1: The move by the Anaklia Development Consortium (ADC) – which was founded by a rival to the head of Georgia’s ruling party – came after the government blamed it for failing to raise enough money for the port and terminated its contract in January. ADC
column2: for its part

Political elite

The incoming Emmerson Mnangagwa also helped Mugabe in ensuring that the rule of law only favoured the political elite. It is an era that has become all too familiar on the continent.

It is currently playing itself out in South African television screens where the parliamentary select committee on public enterprises is probing how a select few individuals came to reap benefits that were meant for all.

Nearly every witness has told of how they were called into meetings with the Guptas to sway tenders and businesses in the politically connected family’s favour.

It is the modern politics of greed that has replaced a common purpose among many African states. It is characterised by how a minority lives an opulent life in the midst of poverty.

column1: Sebastien	Robert Gabriel Mugabe	individual	https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/robert-mugabe-zimbabwean-leader-who-helped-liberate-and-destroy-his-country-dies-at-95/2019/09/06/165c0f62-d06a-11e9-87fa-8501a456c003_story.html	"Robert Mugabe
column2: the Zimbab­wean president who rose to power as a champion of anti-colonial struggle but during 37 years of authoritarian rule presided over the impoverishment and degradation of one of sub-Saharan Africa’s most promising countries
column3: died Sept. 6 at a hospital in Singapore. He was 95.

column1: Zimbabwe’s current leader
column2: Emmerson Mnangagwa
column3: announced the death on Twitter but did not disclose the cause. Mr. Mugabe
column4: who had displayed physical decline over recent years
column5: had been receiving hospital treatment in Singapore since April
column6: Mnangagwa said last month. Singapore’s Foreign Ministry said his body would be flown back to Zimbabwe.

column1: Mr. Mugabe was forced to resign as Zimbabwe’s leader days after the army staged a coup in November 2017. At the time
column2: he was the world’s oldest head of state and one of Africa’s longest-serving leaders.

column1: Mnangagwa
column2: who served as Mr. Mugabe’s vice president
column3: is a wily and resilient veteran of Zimbabwe’s independence war who once led the feared internal security service. Nicknamed “the Crocodile” for his quick-to-strike survival skills
column4: Mnangagwa replaced the ailing Mr. Mugabe in the 2017 coup
column5: then was narrowly elected president last year.

column1: Mnangagwa has struggled to achieve the economic recovery he promised and has cracked down on opponents with some of the same repressive measures Mr. Mugabe’s regime wielded
column2: causing some Zimbabweans to say they missed Mr. Mugabe.

column1: Mr. Mugabe’s fall marked the end of one of the last surviving “Big Men” of the continent
column2: the onetime revolutionary leaders who inherited the security apparatus of their former colonial rulers and used an iron fist to enrich themselves and repress their citizens.
Mr. Mugabe took power in what was once white-minority-ruled Southern Rhodesia after a protracted civil war. He pledged pragmatism and reconciliation. But after a promising start
column3: the country once known as the breadbasket of southern Africa descended into a nightmare of widespread unemployment
column4: hyperinflation
column5: hunger and disease.

column1: Mr. Mugabe and his cronies unleashed gangs of armed thugs to beat up
column2: torture and kill their political foes
column3: while suffocating Zimbabwe’s fledgling democratic institutions. The regime used food aid as a way to reward supporters and starve opponents. Epidemics of AIDS and cholera ravaged rural areas
column4: and the country’s once-thriving commercial farms were gutted.

column1: Cities swelled with hundreds of thousands of displaced people from the countryside. In 2005
column2: Mr. Mugabe pitilessly carried out “Operation Drive Out the Trash
column3: ” an urban beautification effort that made hundreds of thousands of slum dwellers homeless.

column1: Cars waited in line for days outside filling stations
column2: rationing left most people with electricity only every other day
column3: and residents went shopping with suitcases filled with almost worthless currency
column4: its value falling by the hour.

column1: Mugabe resigns under military pressure after 37 years as Zimbabwe’s leader
Mr. Mugabe blamed those ills and more on a long list of enemies
column2: foreign and domestic
column3: while portraying himself as a beleaguered African hero. He conjured a paranoid vision of a major conspiracy led by white farmers and business executives and their black political puppets
column4: and funded by evil governments in London and Washington.

column1: But Mr. Mugabe’s downfall came not at the hands of foreign enemies but from his once-loyal generals. They rebelled against his attempt to install his mercurial wife
column2: Grace Mugabe
column3: as his successor
column4: and placed him under house arrest. Thousands marched in the streets to support Mr. Mugabe’s ouster
column5: while his former allies in the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF) expelled him from his role as party chairman
column6: an ignominious collapse for the only elected leader Zimbabwe had ever known.

column1: As he steered his country over a cliff
column2: many observers puzzled over how a leader once considered principled
column3: intelligent and incorruptible could have descended so far and so quickly. But the seeds of Mr. Mugabe’s ruinous reign were there almost from the start.

column1: A rebel rises to power
The son of a carpenter
column2: Robert Gabriel Mugabe was born Feb. 21
column4: in the village of Kutama in what was then the British colony of Southern Rhodesia.

column1: He was educated in Jesuit missionary schools and in 1951 graduated from South Africa’s University of Fort Hare
column2: Nelson Mandela’s alma mater and the incubator for a generation of activists who led the struggle against white-

column1: minority regimes throughout southern Africa. (Mr. Mugabe later earned several other degrees
column2: some while in prison.)

column1: He returned to Rhodesia in 1960 and joined the Zimbabwe African People’s Union
column2: the dominant black liberation movement led by Joshua Nkomo. But stifled by Nkomo’s autocratic leadership
column3: Mr. Mugabe and a group of insurgents walked out three years later to form the rival ZANU-PF.

column1: Rhodesia’s white-minority government under Prime Minister Ian Smith defied the winds of change that swept across Africa in the early 1960s and unilaterally declared its independence from Britain in 1965
column2: locking up thousands of political opponents. Mr. Mugabe spent more than 10 years in prison without trial. While he was incarcerated
column3: his young son died in 1966 of a form of malaria
column4: and he was denied permission to attend the funeral.

column2: the conflict between Smith’s government and the black opposition erupted into a full-scale civil war in which more than 30
column3: 000 people died. When Mr. Mugabe was released in 1974 in one of several abortive peace efforts
column4: he joined his comrades in the bush. A self-declared Marxist
column5: Mr. Mugabe was considered a shy
column7: in marked contrast with his hardened comrades.

column1: Like many liberation movements
column2: Mr. Mugabe’s was a hothouse of suspicion and betrayal. Many members died under mysterious circumstances — sometimes at the hands of white assassins
column3: other times by the long knives of their comrades. As leader
column4: Mr. Mugabe rode the back of a tiger; had he ever fallen off
column5: he too

column1: One year after Mugabe’s historic ouster
column2: Zimbabwe looks much the same

column1: He developed a sharp contempt for the British government
column2: which was unable to bring Smith’s regime to heel; for the Soviet Union
column3: which backed his rival
column4: Nkomo
column5: during the liberation struggle; and for the West in general
column6: whose sanctions campaign against Rhodesia was halfhearted and ineffective.

column1: Smith’s putative allies in South Africa
column2: fearing that the conflict was destabilizing the region
column3: finally forced his government into peace talks. Mr. Mugabe emerged from exile and won a decisive majority in the country’s first free election in 1980
column4: the year the country became known as Zimbabwe.

column1: He came to power — as prime minister and
column2: starting in 1987
column3: as president — initially pledging to bury old animosities.

column1: “If yesterday you hated me
column2: today you cannot avoid the love that binds you to me and me to you
column3: ” he solemnly told his countrymen April 18
column4: 1980. Still
column5: even in those early days
column6: he warned that “the open hand of reconciliation
column8: could turn into a clenched fist.”

column1: Devolution of a nation
Paranoia was one legacy of the war. Mr. Mugabe
column2: as elected leader
column3: characterized political opponents as “enemies
column4: ” freely used detention without trial and other emergency powers that he inherited from the white regime
column5: and intimidated opponents in his drive for a one-party state.

column1: Each year
column2: he sent several thousand soldiers — spearheaded by the North Korean-trained Fifth Brigade — into southwestern Matabeleland
column3: Nkomo’s ethnic and political stronghold
column4: ostensibly to root out armed dissidents. The main victims of these campaigns
column5: which killed several thousand people

column1: Nkomo eventually submitted
column2: folding his party into Mr. Mugabe’s ruling organization in return for an end to the brutal attacks against his followers.

column1: Mr. Mugabe struggled at times to placate various blocs within his power base
column2: the country’s Shona-speaking majority. Divisions within these blocs were geographic and tribal as well as ideological. Mr. Mugabe worked to hold together a consensus in part through dispensing jobs and patronage to his allies and targeting common enemies
column3: real and imagined.

column1: He singled out Zimbabwe’s small gay community
column2: among other groups
column3: denouncing LGBT individuals as “lower than dogs and pigs” and ordering the expulsion of a gay organization from the Zimbabwe International Book Fair in 1995. He claimed that homosexuality had been unknown in Africa before European colonization and blamed it for the AIDS crisis
column4: when in fact heterosexual activity was the main cause of AIDS in Africa.

column1: After his first wife
column2: the former Sally Hayfron
column3: died in 1992
column4: Mr. Mugabe married his secretary and longtime mistress
column5: Grace Marufu

Defenders of Trump and Tillerson argue there are valid privacy concerns behind holding back their tax information. Privacy is important
column71: as enshrined in US law - but it has to be balanced against the public good. As candidates for high public office
column72: Trump and Tillerson’s right to privacy is far outweighed by the need for the public to know that they have paid their dues to society.\xa0 As President Nixon said
column73: \xa0“people have got to know whether or not their president is a crook”\xa0– the same applies to their top diplomat. To eliminate any doubt
column74: Tillerson should release his returns to the Senate
column75:
just as dozens of Republican and Democrat nominees have done before him.

\n\n

This raises questions about one of the pillars of the Trump victory. When he speaks about “draining the swamp” it’s easy to imagine a massive cull of political elites corrupted by financial interests.\xa0 What’s happening now is very different.\xa0 In casting itself as a team of political outsiders
column76: the Trump campaign has managed to shield itself from accountability and protect its business interests. They are merging the worlds of big business and its regulators
column77: without recognition of the impact this will have on the people they are there to serve.\xa0 The heads of big business
column78: with secretive financial dealings and no public service record whatsoever
column79: are moving into our nation’s highest seats of power
column80:
and disregarding norms designed to hold them to account.

\n\n

Exxon’s track record under Tillerson on transparency is dire. The natural resource sector is famously corrupt – the world’s most corrupt industry according to the OECD. But Exxon and other oil companies can no longer hide behind the excuse of confidentiality. Increasingly
column81: companies are expected to disclose what they pay in taxes and other payments to governments of countries whose natural resources they extract. This is now required under laws of the US and 30 other countries
column82: as well as international initiatives. The Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) is a global standard which aims to put information about government revenues from natural resource deals into the public domain in 51 countries including the United States. This includes the taxes these companies pay
column83:
which is key to ensuring citizens know what benefits they get from their natural resources.

\n\n

An ongoing anti-corruption probe involving Exxon in Nigeria highlights the need for strong transparency rules. Authorities in Nigeria are investigating how Exxon reportedly paid $600 million to renew three oil licenses that may have been valued by the Nigerian government at $2.55 billion
column84:
according to documents seen by Global Witness. Improved payment transparency will shed light on and deter these types of questionable deals.

\n\n

Exxon publicly supports these transparency efforts: it has long maintained a seat on the EITI’s international board
column85: and also has a representative on the domestic US EITI governing body. In reality
column87: Exxon has mastered the art of paying lip service to transparency while doing all it can to undermine these efforts \xa0\xa0behind the scenes. Exxon is refusing to publish its US tax payments
column88: in contrast to some of its competitors such as BP and Shell. And like Trump
column89: Exxon is not just side-stepping the rules – it is actively trying to bring them down. Mr. Tillerson served as a chairman of the American Petroleum Institute
column90:
a powerful oil lobby group that has fought against a Congressionally-mandated regulation to disclose natural resource payments.

\n\n

It is now the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations’ job to decide whether Tillerson is the right person for such an important appointment. With his and Exxon’s track record of keeping critical information away from scrutiny and actively undermining attempts to fight corruption
column91:
they must consider if he is really fit to serve the American people.

\n\n'

column153: had on his deathbed passed on his turban

column201: he gave up the idea of residing in it. It was
column203:

column205: became the new pride of place. Nawab sahib was clearly taken by Italian architectural vocabulary. But this time
column206:

column207: in no fewer than thirteen years of painstaking intricate work

column211:
and pillars with Doric capitals and the overflowing pot of Laxmi at the base. The Nawab’s fancy was duly matched by the skill of his architect.

column212: its clay ramparts now lined with fired bricks
column213: the place for the traditional dustaar-bundi – the formal donning of the turban of kingship. As well as that
column214: Derawar was the royal burial place. Even today
column215: the stately domes of its many mausoleums
column216: dusty and somewhat the worse for neglect
column217:
not far from the royal mosque recall a past grandeur.

column218: Sadiq Mohammad IV could only enjoy the pleasures of this palace for four years. He died in 1899 leaving his building tradition and his fiefdom to his son Bahawal Khan Abbasi V. column219:

column223:
he began to make his mark by continuing his father’s and grandsire’s superior building tradition.

\n

However
column225: this remarkable and civic-minded ruler with his eye on educational development in his kingdom raised the Bahawalpur Library in the 1930s and Sadiq Public School in the early 1950s. While the library created a reading public
column228:
has produced some very fine women and men to lead in various fields.

\n
column232:
586px"">\n

Long before oil enriched the Saudi kingdom
column233: Nawab Sadiq Mohammad V was shoring up the impoverished kingdom with lavish handouts. Later
column234: though he ceded his kingdom to Pakistan with some hesitation
column235: he was liberal with his financial assistance to the new struggling country. In his largesse
column236: he gifted his private properties to King Edward Medical College and the Punjab University
column237:
besides a large tract of prime real estate to the Punjab government.

\n

In 1955
column238:
Sadiq Mohammad ceded the independent State of Bahawalpur to Punjab province. Eleven years later this able and far-sighted ruler passed away leaving his erstwhile to a progeny that was nowhere near his visionary leadership.

\n

The priceless built heritage of Bahawalpur fell into neglect. Invaluable pieces of fittings and decoration were pilfered by none other than the children of the late Nawab
column239: the very inheritors of it all
column240:
who squabbled over possession of the various properties especially the exquisite Sadiq Garh Palace.

\n

The abandoned palaces of Bahawalpur city may well have crumbled to dust had they not been taken over by the army in the late 1980s. Not all was lost!

\n

Today Sadiq Garh Palace
column244:
its gardens unkempt and its rooms bereft of every adornment. It is a sad testament to the greatness of three of the finest rulers of a bygone dynasty that turned Bahawalpur from sand desert to a very orchard.

TikTok shrugs off Trump attack with expansion plans

Published
28 October

TikTok is continuing to expand despite coming under attack from the Trump administration in the US.

The Chinese-owned firm has announced a tie-up with online retailer Shopify to help businesses create video ads to promote their products.

TikTok also plans to take on around 3
column59: 000 engineers over the next three years
column60:
a spokesman told the BBC.

The popular short-form video app is being forced to sell its US operations to an American company or face a ban.

TikTok\'s Chinese parent company ByteDance will hire the engineers mostly in Europe
column62: the US and Singapore ""to support our rapid global growth
column63:
it said.

It currently employs about 1
column65:
with nearly half of them based in California.

Last month
column66: it emerged that ByteDance plans to invest billions of dollars and recruit hundreds of employees in Singapore
column67:
which has been selected as its South East Asia headquarters.

  • Singapore becomes hub for Chinese tech amid US tensions
  • Anti-Trump TikTokkers not declaring paid content
  • TikTok Ban: How did TikTok stay online in the US?

The Trump administration says Chinese-owned social media platforms such as TikTok and Tencent\'s WeChat pose a national security threat
column68:
claiming users\' data can be accessed by the Chinese government.

Both companies have repeatedly denied these allegations.

Despite the US uncertainty
column69:
TikTok continues to push ahead with its hiring expansion plan and moves into e-commerce.

Video ads

On Tuesday
column70:
Canada-based Shopify said it was tying up with TikTok in the US to allow businesses to create and track video ads.

Shopify said the partnership allows its one million merchants to sell products in the form of ""shoppable video ads"".

TikTok users can click on the ad to buy the product via Shopify. The tie-up will be available first in the US
column71:
where the Chinese app has around 100 million users.

There are plans to roll out the global partnership across Europe and South East Asia early next year.

""We\'ve seen that our community loves connecting with the brands they\'re passionate about
column72:
said a TikTok spokesman.

US ban

In August
column73: Donald Trump signed executive orders against TikTok\'s parent company
column74:
but these have been challenged in US courts.

One of these orders forces ByteDance to sell its US operations by 12 November
column75: one week after the presidential election
column76:
or face a ban.

A last-minute deal to sell TikTok\'s US business to Oracle and Walmart is currently being reviewed with question marks over what stakes the different firms will take.

In June
column77:
Walmart also partnered with Shopify to expand its online marketplace business and tap into the huge surge in online shopping during the virus pandemic.

A judge will consider on 4 November if the US government will be allowed to ban downloads of TikTok from US app stores.
